text.text: Welcome to the Design Digital Lounge!

blocks.alt_text: A multi-colored paintbrush on a black background

text.text: Welcome to the WWDC22 Design Digital Lounge! We’ve got an exciting week planned for you. You can find the full schedule of events on the <https://developer.apple.com/news/?id=dtpm394g| Apple Developer app and on developer.apple.com> beginning June 6 after the Keynote, and activities for all lounges kick off on June 7.
If you haven't already, please take a moment to familiarize yourself with <https://developer.apple.com/news/?id=735utu4s|how the Digital Lounges will work>.

We want to make sure these spaces are helpful and welcoming for everyone — developers and Apple employees alike. Please review and follow the <https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/policies/interactive-events/1/Apple-Developer-WWDC22-Interactive-Events-Attendance-Policy.pdf| WWDC22 Interactive Events Policy>.

messages.text:
:wave: Helloooo! Thank you so much for joining us here in our first _Design Ice Breaker_! This next hour is all about getting to know each other, having fun and talking about all the things that make our design community great.

I’ll be posting questions every so often. I can’t wait to hear your responses in the threads! This may get chaotic in here, but that’s the fun of it – let’s get started!

elements.text: Helloooo! Thank you so much for joining us here in our first

! This next hour is all about getting to know each other, having fun and talking about all the things that make our design community great.

I’ll be posting questions every so often. I can’t wait to hear your responses in the threads! This may get chaotic in here, but that’s the fun of it – let’s get started!

messages.text: First up! Designers come from all types of backgrounds – did you study it? Come from a different field? Practice a different type of design? Just interested in it? Tell us about your path here!

elements.text: First up! Designers come from all types of backgrounds – did you study it? Come from a different field? Practice a different type of design? Just interested in it? Tell us about your path here!

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Depends on how involved you are, as a designer, in the project. The more involved with the development team, they more they would probably have to know some basic Comp Sci concepts in order for their designs to be feasible with both efficiency and other factors.

I usually prototype my idea by starting with some basic paper sketches of what the app will do. From there I make a web map of the contents of the app, and then I would move on to making a basic wireframe concept of the app, defining more of the UI for the app as I'd progress.

Designers shouldn't have to code IMO, but it's always nice to have some knowledge for when you're designing things, so you can avoid doing things that can't really be done in code.

Also prototyping, mainly Figma nowadays. It's just so easy, and makes the timeline from ideation to prototype lightning fast :zap:

I’ve been experimenting with <http://origami.design|Origami> recently, tons of great patches to create rich interactions and animations. But I’ve been starting to learn SwiftUI to prototype more advanced ideas! :nerd_face:

elements.text: recently, tons of great patches to create rich interactions and animations. But I’ve been starting to learn SwiftUI to prototype more advanced ideas!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I am Marcus, and I am an iOS programmer by trade who is interested in learning more about mobile design. I'd say my favorite piece of design would be the recent trend of more general flat designs (e.g., Coinbase, Twitter, etc). I'm generally a huge fan of this design trend due to how second nature concepts like grids come with these designs.

:wave: I’m Chris, I design and build a family of music apps (ChordBank). I have to say, my favorite piece of design I ever saw was the juxtaposition of two objects at the Cooper Hewitt museum: A spacesuit from the 1990s, next to the most intricuit inuit parka from… I’m not exactly sure when but much earlier than that made out of, I think, some kind of  whale intestine. Floored me to see two very different cultures solving similar problems with very different technologies.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: This is a portrait I drew from my imagination on my iPhone. I'm happy how it turned out.

The thing I'm proud having come up with recently is more a method than a product: it's a way to select variants of a tint when working on a colour palette. Colour has always been difficult for me, still is, so this might explain the pride. It builds upon <@U03DMQBFPH8>'s work at Lyft (thanks!), as described in <https://bureau.tsailly.net/2022/03/color-variations.html|this post>. Tools play a great role in shaping the products we come up with, so we have to be picky about them, improve them when possible, and come up with some others if need be.

messages.text:
<@U03JRP87THN> asked
> After creating a new custom symbol, how do we add it to our app? Is it like any other SF Symbol?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"After creating a new custom symbol, how do we add it to our app? Is it like any other SF Symbol?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: After you've made and annotated your symbol in the app, choose File > Export Symbol... and bring the resulting SVG into an Xcode asset catalog. Then, you can access it like other embedded images.

elements.text: After you've made and annotated your symbol in the app, choose File > Export Symbol... and bring the resulting SVG into an Xcode asset catalog. Then, you can access it like other embedded images.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thank you very much!

messages.text:
<@U03HVFJUN14> asked
> Is there a way to transfer your own custom symbols with all the settings between different Mac's or pass it to other co-designers?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Is there a way to transfer your own custom symbols with all the settings between different Mac's or pass it to other co-designers?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The file created when you choose File > Export Symbol... can be shared with other people. It can be imported back in to the SF Symbols app and should preserve all of the annotations, too!

elements.text: The file created when you choose File > Export Symbol... can be shared with other people. It can be imported back in to the SF Symbols app and should preserve all of the annotations, too!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Oh nice, so it’s basically an SVG that’s on steroids. :smile: Or is it a different file format?

elements.text: Oh nice, so it’s basically an SVG that’s on steroids.
Or is it a different file format?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yep, File > Export Symbol will give you an SVG. If you plan on sharing it with other designers it’s best to export the latest version (4.0) so that new features like monochrome layers + variable color are included

elements.text: Yep, File > Export Symbol will give you an SVG. If you plan on sharing it with other designers it’s best to export the latest version (4.0) so that new features like monochrome layers + variable color are included

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Awesome. Thanks a lot for! :pray::slightly_smiling_face:

We don't recommend editing the SVGs that come out of the `File > Export Symbol...`  option, however, they're just intended for data delivery. The recommended workflow is to use `File > Export Template...` if you want to edit the shape of the symbol, bring that template back into the SF Symbols app, do your annotation within the app, and then use `File > Export Symbol...` for delivery.

messages.text:
<@U03J4BG14R2> asked
> Is it possible to assign colors dynamically to SF Symbols rendering in multicolor mode?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Is it possible to assign colors dynamically to SF Symbols rendering in multicolor mode?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Multicolor rendering mode uses the colors assigned to the symbol by the designer. Use palette mode to use a dynamic set of colors.

elements.text: Multicolor rendering mode uses the colors assigned to the symbol by the designer. Use palette mode to use a dynamic set of colors.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: There are some parts of symbols in multicolor that are still controlled by colors you specify, however. For example, `folder.fill.badge.plus` in multicolor will keep the badge's colors locked to green and white, but you still have control over the color of the folder.

elements.text: There are some parts of symbols in multicolor that are still controlled by colors you specify, however. For example,
in multicolor will keep the badge's colors locked to green and white, but you still have control over the color of the folder.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Is it possible to dynamically assign multiple colors to the symbol rendering in palette mode?

elements.text: Is it possible to dynamically assign multiple colors to the symbol rendering in palette mode?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yes. SwiftUI allows multiple foreground styles, and AppKit & UIKit allow an array of colors for palette mode

elements.text: Yes. SwiftUI allows multiple foreground styles, and AppKit & UIKit allow an array of colors for palette mode

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Amazing! Thanks for answering I will do some reading on how to do it

elements.text: Amazing! Thanks for answering I will do some reading on how to do it

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The API for AppKit/UIKit is `configurationWithPaletteColors:` which takes an array of colors

elements.text: which takes an array of colors

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
And in SwiftUI what you want is the `.foregroundStyle` modifier:
<https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/view/foregroundstyle(_:)>

elements.text: And in SwiftUI what you want is the

<@U03JNAGPDS6> asked
> When creating new symbols, what criteria is followed? I’ve wanted to make custom symbols before but want it to match with the rest of the rest of the SF Symbol catalog.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"When creating new symbols, what criteria is followed? I\u2019ve wanted to make custom symbols before but want it to match with the rest of the rest of the SF Symbol catalog."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Awesome, we have Thalia here to answer this.

elements.text: Awesome, we have Thalia here to answer this.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I’m sure it might take a minute to compose her many thoughts…

elements.text: I’m sure it might take a minute to compose her many thoughts…

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I would start with looking at the symbols in the context of other symbols. For example, if you are drawing a symbol about astronomy, you would want to looks at symbols that are lated like the moon, stars, etc.

elements.text: I would start with looking at the symbols in the context of other symbols. For example, if you are drawing a symbol about astronomy, you would want to looks at symbols that are lated like the moon, stars, etc.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: From there, I would start by defining the proportions, not too wide, not too tall, all related to the other symbols.

elements.text: From there, I would start by defining the proportions, not too wide, not too tall, all related to the other symbols.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: And next I'll try to match the stroke thickness, roundness of the shapes, angles. It all depends on what you are trying to draw.

elements.text: And next I'll try to match the stroke thickness, roundness of the shapes, angles. It all depends on what you are trying to draw.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Let's say you need a telescope. Then I'll probably try to match some of the angles of other symbols.

elements.text: Let's say you need a telescope. Then I'll probably try to match some of the angles of other symbols.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: It's about looking at the context and iterating to get the best results. It's also good to look at the symbol in small and big sizes, to craft the best drawing possible for all scenarios.

elements.text: It's about looking at the context and iterating to get the best results. It's also good to look at the symbol in small and big sizes, to craft the best drawing possible for all scenarios.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Matching the line weight within SF Symbols is a good metric to follow. Also, referencing the scale and alignment of SF Symbols for shapes that are similar to what you are trying to make is a good place to start. For example, if your custom symbol is circular, scale it similar to a circle in SF Symbols.

elements.text: Matching the line weight within SF Symbols is a good metric to follow. Also, referencing the scale and alignment of SF Symbols for shapes that are similar to what you are trying to make is a good place to start. For example, if your custom symbol is circular, scale it similar to a circle in SF Symbols.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: A big advantage is that there are so many symbols to choose from so extending the library is easy. And also the way symbols are designed to work with text (font weight matching, small and large variants). Right to left support

elements.text: A big advantage is that there are so many symbols to choose from so extending the library is easy. And also the way symbols are designed to work with text (font weight matching, small and large variants). Right to left support

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
As I said in the talk last year, the kind of design that requires no additional work from me is the *best* kind of design! :stuck_out_tongue_closed_eyes:

But really, the team has been working on SF Symbols as a way to help people make apps that look fantastic and blend seamlessly with the rest of Apple platforms. Even *more* importantly, SF Symbols are also designed with accessibility and inclusivity in mind. They react to things like Dynamic Type and Increased Contrast automatically, which is a big win for users of your app.

elements.text: As I said in the talk last year, the kind of design that requires no additional work from me is the
But really, the team has been working on SF Symbols as a way to help people make apps that look fantastic and blend seamlessly with the rest of Apple platforms. Even

importantly, SF Symbols are also designed with accessibility and inclusivity in mind. They react to things like Dynamic Type and Increased Contrast automatically, which is a big win for users of your app.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Symbols offer many benefits: visual craft and integration with the system font, accessibility features including localized variants for many languages and scripts. Familiarity with users across the platforms. Smaller app footprint.

elements.text: Symbols offer many benefits: visual craft and integration with the system font, accessibility features including localized variants for many languages and scripts. Familiarity with users across the platforms. Smaller app footprint.

<@U03HVE4TV8E> asked
> Hey! Thanks for the epic video! Is there anyway to use new symbols from iOS 16 in iOS 15 and below? Thanks :grinning:

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Hey! Thanks for the epic video! Is there anyway to use new symbols from iOS 16 in iOS 15 and below? Thanks "},{"type":"emoji","name":"grinning"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: It's possible to export a new symbol using `File > Export Symbol...` and bring that into your app to support lower deployment targets. Remember to adjust the symbol version accordingly, though! 3.0 for last year's releases and 2.0 for the year before that.

elements.text: It's possible to export a new symbol using
and bring that into your app to support lower deployment targets. Remember to adjust the symbol version accordingly, though! 3.0 for last year's releases and 2.0 for the year before that.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Note that you can still use the latest template format (4.0) with custom symbols even when deploying to earlier deployment targets as long as you are using Xcode 14 to compile your app.  Naturally, the new content features won't be present on those earlier releases, so you need to be careful about which template content features you use.  Safest of course is to just export with the older template versions as Paul recommends.

elements.text: Note that you can still use the latest template format (4.0) with custom symbols even when deploying to earlier deployment targets as long as you are using Xcode 14 to compile your app.  Naturally, the new content features won't be present on those earlier releases, so you need to be careful about which template content features you use.  Safest of course is to just export with the older template versions as Paul recommends.

messages.text:
<@U03JRQ62JQY> asked
> I’d love to hear more about what it was like working on this massive update to SF Symbols. How do you go about figuring out which symbols to choose? Is there a lot of collaboration across teams within Apple for such projects? Also: amazing work!

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"I\u2019d love to hear more about what it was like working on this massive update to SF Symbols. How do you go about figuring out which symbols to choose? Is there a lot of collaboration across teams within Apple for such projects? Also: amazing work!"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I think I can answer the second part of the question only :wink: but yes, there is definitely a lot of collaboration between teams to define what are the best symbols and design that fit best in the UIs. We want to make the symbols as good as possible, so there is a lot of iterations too!

elements.text: I think I can answer the second part of the question only

but yes, there is definitely a lot of collaboration between teams to define what are the best symbols and design that fit best in the UIs. We want to make the symbols as good as possible, so there is a lot of iterations too!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I can’t imagine the amount of work it must take when the library is so huge and each symbol is so carefully crafted. Thanks for your answer!

elements.text: I can’t imagine the amount of work it must take when the library is so huge and each symbol is so carefully crafted. Thanks for your answer!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: There's also an incredible amount of work that comes in from the frameworks and platform engineering sides to support all these new features like Variable Color and different rendering modes!

elements.text: There's also an incredible amount of work that comes in from the frameworks and platform engineering sides to support all these new features like Variable Color and different rendering modes!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: For adding new symbols: it’s a combination of supporting new platform features, adopting symbols for existing features and identifying concepts that have broad utility and application across a variety of apps and contexts.

elements.text: For adding new symbols: it’s a combination of supporting new platform features, adopting symbols for existing features and identifying concepts that have broad utility and application across a variety of apps and contexts.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks so much for your replies, everyone! I _super_ appreciate all of your hard work! :heart:

elements.text: Thanks so much for your replies, everyone! I
appreciate all of your hard work!

> I may have missed this in the SF Symbols video, but I was wondering: how do these new rendering modes interact with WidgetKit rendering using the new lock screen widget layouts like .accessoryCircular etc?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"I may have missed this in the SF Symbols video, but I was wondering: how do these new rendering modes interact with WidgetKit rendering using the new lock screen widget layouts like .accessoryCircular etc?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Great question. For consistency, we suggest using monochrome, hierarchical, or automatic, but WidgetKit may not actually end up enforcing that in the betas.

messages.text:
<@U03JBMMB10A> asked
> Do variable colors animate automatically when changed?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Do variable colors animate automatically when changed?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hi <@U03JBMMB10A> can you elaborate a bit?
There isn't any animation when the variable color percentage changes and causes a layer to "dim" or "un-dim." The change appears instantly.

elements.text: There isn't any animation when the variable color percentage changes and causes a layer to "dim" or "un-dim." The change appears instantly.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Okay, thank you.
The path color will instantly change according to the corresponding percentage value.

elements.text: The path color will instantly change according to the corresponding percentage value.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Using variable colors does not automatically animate across the visual states. However it is entirely possible to add animation to Symbol just as you would to other UI Images using the UI framework animation facilities of your choice.

elements.text: Using variable colors does not automatically animate across the visual states. However it is entirely possible to add animation to Symbol just as you would to other UI Images using the UI framework animation facilities of your choice.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Right, thank y’all!

elements.text: Alright folks, we’re going to close up shop! Thanks for joining us for MTP: What’s new in SF Symbols. Join us for our daily design discussion at 3pm!

messages.text: Hi everyone! We hope you’re having a great start to WWDC and enjoying today’s sessions, lounges and labs. We’re so excited to have you here!

elements.text: Hi everyone! We hope you’re having a great start to WWDC and enjoying today’s sessions, lounges and labs. We’re so excited to have you here!

messages.text: We’re curious to hear about your experience as designers! What is the most difficult part of the design process to you? Why? :thread:

elements.text: We’re curious to hear about your experience as designers! What is the most difficult part of the design process to you? Why?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Presentation :sweat_smile:

I'm a solo founder with a keen interest in design. I understand layout basics & am comfortable with the mechanics of using Sketch etc. if needed. But, I struggle with developing a _Design Eye_ for what works. Any recommendations other than just studying who won the Design Awards?

elements.text: I'm a solo founder with a keen interest in design. I understand layout basics & am comfortable with the mechanics of using Sketch etc. if needed. But, I struggle with developing a
for what works. Any recommendations other than just studying who won the Design Awards?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Umm, all of it??? My designs just never look right :sweat_smile:

elements.text: Umm, all of it??? My designs just never look right

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Starting the design, when you’re beginning something, you have so many ideas flowing through your head, and it’s hard to choose one! I sometimes get stuck on this, so I draw each idea and choose what looks best.

elements.text: Starting the design, when you’re beginning something, you have so many ideas flowing through your head, and it’s hard to choose one! I sometimes get stuck on this, so I draw each idea and choose what looks best.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: <@U03JELM0ZNV> Looking at other apps not just for inspiration but to understand patterns of what works and what is familiar, is a great way to refine your design eye. But craft also takes practice and iteration. Keep doing the work and you’ll learn and improve :muscle:

elements.text: Looking at other apps not just for inspiration but to understand patterns of what works and what is familiar, is a great way to refine your design eye. But craft also takes practice and iteration. Keep doing the work and you’ll learn and improve

slackdump_thread_replies.text: <@U03JNAGPDS6> That's a lot of work to draw every idea! Do you ask for people's feedback at early stage?

elements.text: That's a lot of work to draw every idea! Do you ask for people's feedback at early stage?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks <@U03HBHWCB4N> it's finding the _other apps_ and having someone say what's good/bad about specifics that I struggle with.

elements.text: and having someone say what's good/bad about specifics that I struggle with.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: <@U03JELM0ZNV> it can be difficult and oftentimes subjective! What makes an app good can rely on _many_ factors. Does it solve a real need? Is it accessible to as many people as possible? Is the content relevant, useful and polished? To understand what is good and bad may also require conversations, critiques or  collaboration with other designers or disciplines.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: <@U03JNAGPDS6> that’s a great approach! consider also test your designs with others, it doesn’t have to be high fidelity, you’ll learn so much about how others think and what do they expect from the UI :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: that’s a great approach! consider also test your designs with others, it doesn’t have to be high fidelity, you’ll learn so much about how others think and what do they expect from the UI

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The problem is people don't always see the potential of an idea if it's not high fidelity :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye:

elements.text: The problem is people don't always see the potential of an idea if it's not high fidelity

slackdump_thread_replies.text: For UX, it’s trying to consider all perspectives and all the ways our users interact with their device. My team has been working on a medical app for cardiologists and I stress about not letting any harm into the world as a result of a design choice (how forgiving should certain actions be, how can someone reverse an accidental action, is every corner fully VoiceOver-labeled and contrast is correct in both color schemes, etc) -Sam

elements.text: For UX, it’s trying to consider all perspectives and all the ways our users interact with their device. My team has been working on a medical app for cardiologists and I stress about not letting any harm into the world as a result of a design choice (how forgiving should certain actions be, how can someone reverse an accidental action, is every corner fully VoiceOver-labeled and contrast is correct in both color schemes, etc) -Sam

slackdump_thread_replies.text: When I’m in visual design mode, the main difficulty is trying to balance uniqueness (or branding) while staying true to the platform. -Sam

elements.text: When I’m in visual design mode, the main difficulty is trying to balance uniqueness (or branding) while staying true to the platform. -Sam

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Design decisions have the potential to really impact peoples lives. I like that you’re empathizing with the weight of those decisions!

elements.text: Design decisions have the potential to really impact peoples lives. I like that you’re empathizing with the weight of those decisions!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: <@U03H3LD2M2T> True! I found useful to set the right expectations about what I want and don’t want feedback about. That way if the Visual Design is not ready, they know they should only focus on reviewing the experience.

elements.text: True! I found useful to set the right expectations about what I want and don’t want feedback about. That way if the Visual Design is not ready, they know they should only focus on reviewing the experience.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: (Sorry for the bummer reply :grimacing:)
Not a bummer, as designers we should be aware of the impact of our work! I’m glad you brought it up

messages.text: <@U03DMQBFPH8> added a workflow to this channel: *Design - Ask a Question*.

*Welcome to Q&A with the HIG Team*! For the next hour, we’re looking forward to answering your questions about the Human Interface Guidelines, what went into the redesign, and related things! (Did you know we just redesigned it???)

Select the:heavy_plus_sign:icon from the lower left, and find the _Ask A Question_ workflow. Type in your question and it will be delivered directly to the team. We’ll answer as many questions as we can. While it’s unlikely we’ll be able to address every question, all your submissions are valuable; thank you for taking the time! :rocket:

Let’s kick it off! 🪩 And welcome HIG team! <@U03HJ86L1BL> <@U03H3HNAGSK> <@U03HKV4V1FW> <@U03HBJXV0TY> <@U03H3LD2M2T> <@U03HJ7LRK43>

messages.text:
<@U03JELQLESV> asked
> Thank you for the new HIG! Especially appreciate that it starts from UI elements and themes and then mentions platform considerations, instead of being branched off into different platforms only. 
> 
> Are there good examples that come to mind of intentionally breaking the HIG for good reason (after knowing it well)?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Thank you for the new HIG! Especially appreciate that it starts from UI elements and themes and then mentions platform considerations, instead of being branched off into different platforms only. \n\nAre there good examples that come to mind of intentionally breaking the HIG for good reason (after knowing it well)?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Great question! I think that starts coming down to the customization you'd love to do for the app. For example there's no hard and fast rule that you *have* to use SF Symbols, or Apple Typefaces or a specific aesthetic for your app (and that's even more true for games).

Think of the HIG as a great "base" for what you're doing, and tailor the guidance based on what makes the most sense for your users!

elements.text: Great question! I think that starts coming down to the customization you'd love to do for the app. For example there's no hard and fast rule that you

to use SF Symbols, or Apple Typefaces or a specific aesthetic for your app (and that's even more true for games).

Think of the HIG as a great "base" for what you're doing, and tailor the guidance based on what makes the most sense for your users!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: <@U03HJ86L1BL>’s also done a great job at wording the language of the HIG so we rarely ever say "don't" or "never" unless that's really true.

elements.text: ’s also done a great job at wording the language of the HIG so we rarely ever say "don't" or "never" unless that's really true.

messages.text:
<@U03J4D1FEP6> asked
> What are the key changes in the advice being given in the revised HIG, if any?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"What are the key changes in the advice being given in the revised HIG, if any?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hey Duncan, a lot of the content in the HIG carries through from previous versions. But a lot of the older content was adjusted for clarity and we removed things that no longer seemed all that relevant. It’s hard to go through all the specifics but pretty much every page needed to be edited.

elements.text: Hey Duncan, a lot of the content in the HIG carries through from previous versions. But a lot of the older content was adjusted for clarity and we removed things that no longer seemed all that relevant. It’s hard to go through all the specifics but pretty much every page needed to be edited.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We also started adding in new guidance for iOS 16, macOS Ventura, and watchOS 9 (though there’s still a lot more coming this summer

elements.text: We also started adding in new guidance for iOS 16, macOS Ventura, and watchOS 9 (though there’s still a lot more coming this summer

slackdump_thread_replies.text: One example I recall was the Buttons page. There was content in there about placard buttons and bezel buttons but those really aren’t used these days

elements.text: One example I recall was the Buttons page. There was content in there about placard buttons and bezel buttons but those really aren’t used these days

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We also removed some of the content about full color icons in toolbars, for example, since that’s not something modern apps do all that much of.

elements.text: We also removed some of the content about full color icons in toolbars, for example, since that’s not something modern apps do all that much of.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Another key change is in perspective: Rather than starting with guidance for an iOS experience, the revised HIG encourages designing the experience first and then adjusting it as needed to run great on each platform.

elements.text: Another key change is in perspective: Rather than starting with guidance for an iOS experience, the revised HIG encourages designing the experience first and then adjusting it as needed to run great on each platform.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We added a lot of new information in the Patterns section for things like Searching or Sharing. That kind of content was spread out in component pages previously and missed a lot of important information and context when it was tied to specific controls

elements.text: We added a lot of new information in the Patterns section for things like Searching or Sharing. That kind of content was spread out in component pages previously and missed a lot of important information and context when it was tied to specific controls

messages.text:
<@U03J20D4Q03> asked
> First off, congrats on the new HIG! I love how much more comprehensive it is. What are best practices when designing an app that is cross platform? Should the app design's adapt to the respective OS' design guidelines e.g. HIG on iOS, Material You on Android, and Fluent on Windows, or stick with one for a consistent user experience across different platforms (even though it might look slightly out of place depending on the OS)?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"First off, congrats on the new HIG! I love how much more comprehensive it is. What are best practices when designing an app that is cross platform? Should the app design's adapt to the respective OS' design guidelines e.g. HIG on iOS, Material You on Android, and Fluent on Windows, or stick with one for a consistent user experience across different platforms (even though it might look slightly out of place depending on the OS)?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The best approach is to follow the relevant platform conventions. Many of them exist because of how the hardware functions. So ignoring that leads to software that feels disconnected from the hardware.

elements.text: The best approach is to follow the relevant platform conventions. Many of them exist because of how the hardware functions. So ignoring that leads to software that feels disconnected from the hardware.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I also wonder to what extent it's applicable to the web, especially considering seeing more web apps coming from Apple!
Apps that are designed once for all platforms will never feel right everywhere

elements.text: Apps that are designed once for all platforms will never feel right everywhere

slackdump_thread_replies.text: It does apply, there are differences in conventions between web and apps.

elements.text: It does apply, there are differences in conventions between web and apps.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Some of the difference are pretty easy to address. Like not using “Click this button” in an app that only runs on touch screen devices

elements.text: Some of the difference are pretty easy to address. Like not using “Click this button” in an app that only runs on touch screen devices

slackdump_thread_replies.text: ^ huge pet peeve! Also Android and iOS differ a lot in how "back" functionality works for example. So making sure that the design patterns follow system conventions helps quite a bit to not make your app feel like it's alien to the platform

elements.text: ^ huge pet peeve! Also Android and iOS differ a lot in how "back" functionality works for example. So making sure that the design patterns follow system conventions helps quite a bit to not make your app feel like it's alien to the platform

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks for the insight, <@U03HBJXV0TY> and <@U03DMQBFPH8>! They are really helpful. I'll definitely share them with my team who insists on having the same design across different platforms (hamburger menus and FABs everywhere!)

elements.text: ! They are really helpful. I'll definitely share them with my team who insists on having the same design across different platforms (hamburger menus and FABs everywhere!)

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Look I love a good FAB but only when I've designed for Android in the past! Thanks for the question <@U03J20D4Q03> hope that helps because yes, you can be 80%-90% consistent where you can but those platform details matter

elements.text: Look I love a good FAB but only when I've designed for Android in the past! Thanks for the question
hope that helps because yes, you can be 80%-90% consistent where you can but those platform details matter

messages.text:
<@U03JTFWKMMF> asked
> I'd love to know more about the process of evolving the HIG.
> 
> How do you identify things that feel out of date and less relevant, as well as spotting new design trends within Apple that you feel need documenting?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"I'd love to know more about the process of evolving the HIG.\n\nHow do you identify things that feel out of date and less relevant, as well as spotting new design trends within Apple that you feel need documenting?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: This is a great question. Multiple things influence this. One is our work (in evangelism) with developers. Questions that we get during this work can often spark ideas for new areas of guidance, or new details to add to pages

elements.text: This is a great question. Multiple things influence this. One is our work (in evangelism) with developers. Questions that we get during this work can often spark ideas for new areas of guidance, or new details to add to pages

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Another thing that influences the HIG is the work of our design and engineering teams, naturally. As the platforms evolve, there are needs to overhaul pages, or whole sections, to match the direction of the platform (or multiple platforms)

elements.text: Another thing that influences the HIG is the work of our design and engineering teams, naturally. As the platforms evolve, there are needs to overhaul pages, or whole sections, to match the direction of the platform (or multiple platforms)

slackdump_thread_replies.text: +1 to what Doug said! We talk with so many designers throughout the year and for this particular redesign we reached out specifically to the community to get input on where we could improve the HIG.

elements.text: +1 to what Doug said! We talk with so many designers throughout the year and for this particular redesign we reached out specifically to the community to get input on where we could improve the HIG.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I am resisting the urge to point out the various sections that are in need of work now, although I’d like to illustrate the point I’m making by doing so

elements.text: I am resisting the urge to point out the various sections that are in need of work now, although I’d like to illustrate the point I’m making by doing so

messages.text:
<@U03JELQLESV> asked
> What’s stayed the same in the HIG over the past decades?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"What\u2019s stayed the same in the HIG over the past decades?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Although many details have changed, I think it's the keen focus on keeping the user experience at the center of design that's at the heart of the HIG, from the earliest days to the present.

elements.text: Although many details have changed, I think it's the keen focus on keeping the user experience at the center of design that's at the heart of the HIG, from the earliest days to the present.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yes the earliest HIG (I believe from 1977???) continually emphasized the human nature of computers. How computer should conform to people and not the other way around. We are still very much firm believers of this, but with more nuance on what that means ergonomically, inclusively, as a holistic experience.

elements.text: Yes the earliest HIG (I believe from 1977???) continually emphasized the human nature of computers. How computer should conform to people and not the other way around. We are still very much firm believers of this, but with more nuance on what that means ergonomically, inclusively, as a holistic experience.

messages.text:
<@U03J1EHL4KY> asked
> Hi, nice work on the redesign, I've been going through it this morning! I have a question about color.
> 
> On this page: <https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/foundations/dark-mode|https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/foundations/dark-mode> there's the advice "At a minimum, make sure the contrast ratio between colors is no lower than 4.5:1. For custom foreground and background colors, strive for a contrast ratio of 7:1, especially in small text."
> 
> I aim for high contrast as much as possible, but 4.5:1 is pretty limiting, and I don't think Apple always follows this rule themselves. Specifically I'm wondering about the systemColors such as systemOrange, systemMint etc, many of which have quite low contrast against white (i.e., in Light Mode). What is the intended purpose of these colours? Is it meant for text/SF Symbols? Because if so, systemMint comes in at 2.02:1 against white. Should we ever even use systemYellow? Or can we just rely on users turning on Increase Contrast if they need to? But maybe someone doesn't want to have to increase contrast for everything just so they can see that darn yellow text.
> 
> Any insight on the intended use of these systemColors would be greatly appreciated. Thanks!

attachments.fallback: Dark Mode - Foundations - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
attachments.title: Dark Mode - Foundations - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
attachments.text: Dark Mode is a systemwide appearance setting that uses a dark color palette to provide a comfortable viewing experience tailored for low-light environments.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Awesome questions Jessiah! I could take the next 45 minutes trying to answer. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Awesome questions Jessiah! I could take the next 45 minutes trying to answer.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: In short, the rules about color contrast are a bit tricky, it’s not black and white (forgive the pun)

elements.text: In short, the rules about color contrast are a bit tricky, it’s not black and white (forgive the pun)

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Higher contrast is always better but there are mitigating circumstances that make it OK to have lower contrast. For example, text size. The larger or bolder the font, the easier it is to read given the same color value

elements.text: Higher contrast is always better but there are mitigating circumstances that make it OK to have lower contrast. For example, text size. The larger or bolder the font, the easier it is to read given the same color value

slackdump_thread_replies.text: But a color choice that works for large type can be too low contrast for smaller text.

elements.text: But a color choice that works for large type can be too low contrast for smaller text.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The same applies for icons or glyphs (symbols): Finer features are harder to naturally harder to discern so boosting contrast is useful

elements.text: The same applies for icons or glyphs (symbols): Finer features are harder to naturally harder to discern so boosting contrast is useful

I’ve worked on products where I had to incorporate colours that are notoriously difficult to have high contrast - like teal/green.

In those instances i’ve provided darker versions, that are perhaps not so aesthetically pleasing, but pass AA/AAA to assist visually impaired users once they enable accessible system settings. It has worked for me :heart:

slackdump_thread_replies.text: My personal guide when designing is to make all elements that need to be legible and clear have strong contrast. Details like a divider, for example, can be lighter to convey less prominence. But text should always be readable and accessible.

I also feel like I could spend the next hour speaking about this :sweat_smile: so GREAT question. As you might know, the 4.5:1 contrast ratio comes from WCAG 2.0 guidelines. While WCAG 3.0 is still not officially "out" they have an improved way of calculating contrast that I find incredibly interesting: <https://www.w3.org/TR/wcag-3.0/#visual-contrast-of-text>

attachments.fallback: W3C Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 3.0
attachments.title: W3C Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 3.0
attachments.text: The W3C Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 3.0 provide a wide range of recommendations for making web content more accessible to users with disabilities. Following these guidelines will address many of the needs of users with blindness, low vision and other vision impairments; deafness and hearing loss; limited movement and dexterity; speech disabilities; sensory disorders; cognitive and learning disabilities; and combinations of these. These guidelines address accessibility of web content on desktops, laptops, tablets, mobile devices, wearable devices, and other web of things devices. They address various types of web content including static content, interactive content, visual and auditory media, and virtual and augmented reality. The guidelines also address related web tools such as user agents (browsers and assistive technologies), content management systems, authoring tools, and testing tools.

messages.text:
<@U03JMEET43F> asked
> Could you elaborate on any user research (quantitive or qualitative) processes the team uses to shape HIG guidelines?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Could you elaborate on any user research (quantitive or qualitative) processes the team uses to shape HIG guidelines?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: (These questions are good!)

We meet with developers to ask them for feedback on existing content (qualitative). We also regularly talk with developers throughout the year about their apps and, in those conversations, common questions come up that we realize we haven’t really answered in the HIG (or videos). So those turn into ideas about how we can improve the HIG.

elements.text: We meet with developers to ask them for feedback on existing content (qualitative). We also regularly talk with developers throughout the year about their apps and, in those conversations, common questions come up that we realize we haven’t really answered in the HIG (or videos). So those turn into ideas about how we can improve the HIG.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: And the HIG is really a massive collective effort involving design and engineering teams throughout Apple. This HIG is the product of internal experiences where people had misconceptions or questions during the design process that we anticipate designer and developers will have once we ship new features.

elements.text: And the HIG is really a massive collective effort involving design and engineering teams throughout Apple. This HIG is the product of internal experiences where people had misconceptions or questions during the design process that we anticipate designer and developers will have once we ship new features.

messages.text:
<@U03J1UU7HS7> asked
> Curious what your pov is on link buttons, specifically buttons embedded within text content on native.  There are some cases where this type of treatment can make sense and then others where it feels like we’re just pulling over from web.  Do you have any formalized process around when to use and not use this treatment?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Curious what your pov is on link buttons, specifically buttons embedded within text content on native.  There are some cases where this type of treatment can make sense and then others where it feels like we\u2019re just pulling over from web.  Do you have any formalized process around when to use and not use this treatment?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Good question! My sense is that links inline commonly get overlooked because (a) not expected in apps and (b) the color distinction is often too subtle. In general they should be avoided. But there are cases where it can work. One that comes to mind are “More >” links at the end of a paragraph of text where you navigate to a child view to see more. Or expand a partially revealed block of text.

elements.text: Good question! My sense is that links inline commonly get overlooked because (a) not expected in apps and (b) the color distinction is often too subtle. In general they should be avoided. But there are cases where it can work. One that comes to mind are “More >” links at the end of a paragraph of text where you navigate to a child view to see more. Or expand a partially revealed block of text.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: But it’s almost always more clear to use a proper button or table row with a chevron.

elements.text: But it’s almost always more clear to use a proper button or table row with a chevron.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Probably the biggest issue with link style buttons, especially when presented in context of other text, is that the tap target size is too small (not 44pt tall) so tapping accuracy is compromised

elements.text: Probably the biggest issue with link style buttons, especially when presented in context of other text, is that the tap target size is too small (not 44pt tall) so tapping accuracy is compromised

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks for the response.  Right, we’ve certainly argued from an accessibility perspective - tap targets and contrast.  The challenge is (as component devs/designers) to come up with a general alternative.  We’ve seen push back that there is an efficiency to associating an action with a verb in a sentence.  Pulling actions out to separate buttons can end up elevating them.  T&C or legal section, for example.

elements.text: Thanks for the response.  Right, we’ve certainly argued from an accessibility perspective - tap targets and contrast.  The challenge is (as component devs/designers) to come up with a general alternative.  We’ve seen push back that there is an efficiency to associating an action with a verb in a sentence.  Pulling actions out to separate buttons can end up elevating them.  T&C or legal section, for example.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
This is our first year running Digital Lounges across the majority of our teams, and we want to make sure the (very great) questions everyone has get great answers. We’re running activities at specific times to ensure that our designers can answer as many people as possible, and questions don’t fall through the cracks!

In addition, we’ve got a lot of awesome other activities scheduled during WWDC, including design labs — as much as we’d love to hang out all day with everyone here in the lounges, we want to make sure that folks who have requested 1:1 appointments get dedicated time and our designers’ attention isn’t split.

Finally, we’re running some really cool design challenges over in <#C03HKS00DFT|> all week long, and we do offer open posting there from 9 - 6 p.m. PT for folks to collaborate on design ideas.

messages.text:
<@U03JTFWKMMF> asked
> With dynamic type is it expect that all text based content on the interface will scale? Is there a time where that's not appropriate such as in button containers?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"With dynamic type is it expect that all text based content on the interface will scale? Is there a time where that's not appropriate such as in button containers?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Great question. It’s really not possible for ALL text to scale in some cases. Tab bars, for instance, don’t scale because text would truncate immediately which defeats the purpose. And there is an AX setting for showing the tab icon and label in a bezel on tap.

elements.text: Great question. It’s really not possible for ALL text to scale in some cases. Tab bars, for instance, don’t scale because text would truncate immediately which defeats the purpose. And there is an AX setting for showing the tab icon and label in a bezel on tap.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The general approach is to make sure all text in the content area / scroll views scales.

elements.text: The general approach is to make sure all text in the content area / scroll views scales.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Awesome, thanks for the clarification Mike :thumbsup:

elements.text: Awesome, thanks for the clarification Mike

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Text in fixed height elements (like tab / toolbars) is tricker

elements.text: Text in fixed height elements (like tab / toolbars) is tricker

slackdump_thread_replies.text: (1) The person. Is this photo editing for … professionals? influences? some specific person? … I really would start here, even though it’s the obvious designery thing to say, because I think it helps shape what level of detail and density is appropriate

slackdump_thread_replies.text: It gets especially difficult when you try to cater to both, making the app easy to use while also giving advanced users more tools. But that’s for sure a good place to start, professionals are used to different kinds of UIs as well

slackdump_thread_replies.text: (2) The platform will dictate your heuristics around detail and density. messages.text:
<@U03HMCT187R> asked
> Sparked by a previous thread, are yall changing any recommendations for when to use title-case vs sentence-case capitalization style?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Sparked by a previous thread, are yall changing any recommendations for when to use title-case vs sentence-case capitalization style?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Great question! Although the guidance is to use title case in components like button labels and menu items, it also comes down to stylistic choices for the text content within your app.

elements.text: Great question! Although the guidance is to use title case in components like button labels and menu items, it also comes down to stylistic choices for the text content within your app.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: 100%, <@U03HJ86L1BL>! And when it comes to the content within your app, it — and your style guide — is going to evolve over time. As folks in this channel noted, we decided to move to sentence case in the HIG after many years. :slightly_smiling_face: The most important thing is to be consistent — if you’re going to use title case for your content headers, make sure you’re doing that everywhere in your app. If you change that style, make sure you’re adopting it across the board. And final tip: Even if you largely follow the paradigms of a guide like AP or Chicago Style, it’s super helpful to maintain a separate personal style guide for your content — that way, you have a great reference document.

elements.text: ! And when it comes to the content within your app, it — and your style guide — is going to evolve over time. As folks in this channel noted, we decided to move to sentence case in the HIG after many years.

The most important thing is to be consistent — if you’re going to use title case for your content headers, make sure you’re doing that everywhere in your app. If you change that style, make sure you’re adopting it across the board. And final tip: Even if you largely follow the paradigms of a guide like AP or Chicago Style, it’s super helpful to maintain a separate personal style guide for your content — that way, you have a great reference document.

messages.text: Hi everyone! My name is Doug and I’m a Design Evangelist at Apple! Over the next hour, we’ll watch *Design app experiences with charts* together, and we’ll be joined by Nicholas Felton, the presenter himself. We’re also joined by Halden Lin and Lilian de Greef, the presenters of the companion video to this one, *Design an effective chart*.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Oh yummy. Many years ago I wrote 3D stereo movie plugins for QuickTime & used audio logging that ended up sounding a lot like this as the only way to debug what was happening in the codec pipeline.

Super-short series of tones at different points of content processing provided realtime explanation of what was happening. It was all too fast for a textual console log to be useful & activated a different pattern matching area of the brain.

elements.text:
Oh yummy. Many years ago I wrote 3D stereo movie plugins for QuickTime & used audio logging that ended up sounding a lot like this as the only way to debug what was happening in the codec pipeline.

Super-short series of tones at different points of content processing provided realtime explanation of what was happening. It was all too fast for a textual console log to be useful & activated a different pattern matching area of the brain.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Note that you can _nearly_ do this in modern XCode with the *Edit Breakpoints* feature, except there's no choice of sounds so you are stuck with long system sounds. I was using CodeWarrior back in 2000.

<@U03K1SMSPUZ> asked
> More of an abstract question: Taking the Fitness app as an example, the calendar view tends to stick out as a completely separate design pattern. Are there any guidelines on when you would want to implement charting in a calendar as opposed to a tabbed interfaced that grouped by day/week/month etc.?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"More of an abstract question: Taking the Fitness app as an example, the calendar view tends to stick out as a completely separate design pattern. Are there any guidelines on when you would want to implement charting in a calendar as opposed to a tabbed interfaced that grouped by day\/week\/month etc.?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: That's a great question! The Fitness app is focused on a daily activity like closing your rings. Since this is a top-level goal of the app, the calendar view makes it easy to see your successes through time.

elements.text: That's a great question! The Fitness app is focused on a daily activity like closing your rings. Since this is a top-level goal of the app, the calendar view makes it easy to see your successes through time.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The Health app mirrors the same information but in a longitudinal form, where you can see larger trends.

elements.text: The Health app mirrors the same information but in a longitudinal form, where you can see larger trends.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yup that makes sense! I guess what I'm trying to wrap my head around is finding the medium of digest-able information and _too much_ but that's the joy of design!

elements.text: Yup that makes sense! I guess what I'm trying to wrap my head around is finding the medium of digest-able information and
but that's the joy of design!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Each of these approaches has its advantages. The calendar view excels at showing streaks and achievements relative to the day of the week. Conversely, the charts in Health aggregate away those daily details into larger trends.

elements.text: Each of these approaches has its advantages. The calendar view excels at showing streaks and achievements relative to the day of the week. Conversely, the charts in Health aggregate away those daily details into larger trends.

messages.text:
<@U03HMCWU9P1> asked
> What are the best practices for using color in charts (such as considering accessibility for color blindness)?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"What are the best practices for using color in charts (such as considering accessibility for color blindness)?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Great question! We talk about these best practices in the “Color” section of our companion talk, <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/110340/|Design and effective chart>

attachments.fallback: Apple Developer: Design an effective chart - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
attachments.title: Design an effective chart - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
attachments.text: Learn how to design focused, approachable, and accessible charts. We'll show you how to design great charts with clear marks, axes,...

elements.text: Great question! We talk about these best practices in the “Color” section of our companion talk,

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
At a high level, here are some key concepts to think about when using color in charts:
• Use color to enhance
• Consider associated meanings
• Balance visual weight
• Choose distinct colors
• Respect system settings

elements.text: At a high level, here are some key concepts to think about when using color in charts:

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_list","elements":[{"type":"rich_text_section","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Use color to enhance"}]},{"type":"rich_text_section","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Consider associated meanings"}]},{"type":"rich_text_section","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Balance visual weight"}]},{"type":"rich_text_section","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Choose distinct colors"}]},{"type":"rich_text_section","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Respect system settings"}]}],"style":"bullet","indent":0,"border":0}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You can also find general best practices around color in the Human Interface Guidelines: <https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/foundations/color/>

attachments.fallback: Color - Foundations - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
attachments.title: Color - Foundations - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
attachments.text: Judicious use of color can enhance communication, evoke your brand, provide visual continuity, communicate status and feedback, and help people understand information.

elements.text: You can also find general best practices around color in the Human Interface Guidelines:

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hi Axel! Any Chart can be placed in a scroll view, but I'm guessing you are interested in the "pinned" Y axis behavior. You should be able to achieve this with a workaround, that is by ZStacking the Y axis on top of the scrolling chart. Please file a radar if this is a feature you want to get added to the API!

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Hi <@U03J1EHL4KY> great questions!

(1) This might depend on what behavior you're looking for. There currently isn't a pinch + zoom API built directly into Swift Charts, but you could capture a the gesture in a `chartOverlay` and respond to it accordingly by manipulating the scale / data in the chart.

(2) Yes! Absolutely. Using a `chartOverlay` and the provided `ChartProxy` to read the data point being tapped.

There are some great examples of these in the Swift Charts sample app (<https://developer.apple.com/documentation/charts/visualizing_your_app_s_data>)

Check out the "Swift Charts: Raise the bar" talk too! Donghao explains more there. <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10137/>

slackdump_thread_replies.text: When used properly, animation can certainly enhance your chart… even when not tied to user interaction. For example, to indicate that a chart has updated, animating a point or growing a bar can be a helpful and delightful addition.

elements.text: When used properly, animation can certainly enhance your chart… even when not tied to user interaction. For example, to indicate that a chart has updated, animating a point or growing a bar can be a helpful and delightful addition.

<@U03J8GWEFU7> asked
> Could I create an iOS app that once downloaded from the App Store is never really meant to be opened by the user?  Instead it would include App Intents, and primarily be accessed via Siri with just dialogs & custom snippets?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Could I create an iOS app that once downloaded from the App Store is never really meant to be opened by the user?  Instead it would include App Intents, and primarily be accessed via Siri with just dialogs & custom snippets?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: It’s an interesting question <@U03J8GWEFU7> … It’s a paradigm we’ve seen on Apple Watch with watch apps. Some watch apps are really just ways to deliver complications to the watch face, and rich notifications on the watch itself

elements.text: … It’s a paradigm we’ve seen on Apple Watch with watch apps. Some watch apps are really just ways to deliver complications to the watch face, and rich notifications on the watch itself

slackdump_thread_replies.text: However, those watch apps also display the information that is delivered in the complication and notification.

elements.text: However, those watch apps also display the information that is delivered in the complication and notification.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: So anyway, the app matters :muscle:

But technically yes, you can build an app that’s focused on providing App Shortcuts, but when someone taps on your app icon you’ll still have to have a viable experience that explains what it does.

Also, if you support dynamic parameters, your app will need to be be opened for you to update the order.

elements.text:
But technically yes, you can build an app that’s focused on providing App Shortcuts, but when someone taps on your app icon you’ll still have to have a viable experience that explains what it does.

Also, if you support dynamic parameters, your app will need to be be opened for you to update the order.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: So I could make an app that’s intended primarily as a container for Siri first App Intent interactions, and the app itself could just provide some context that explains the Siri functionality?

elements.text: So I could make an app that’s intended primarily as a container for Siri first App Intent interactions, and the app itself could just provide some context that explains the Siri functionality?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You can build that, but if you want to manage your dynamic parameter and people are never opening your app (because it doesn’t have functionality in itself), you won’t be able to re-order or update your parameter values.

elements.text: You can build that, but if you want to manage your dynamic parameter and people are never opening your app (because it doesn’t have functionality in itself), you won’t be able to re-order or update your parameter values.

messages.text:
<@U03HMDHTDU7> asked
> How to create a timer shortcut with shorter phrase for our app if the system already have one, for example, Set a timer for 5 mins, how can we tell the system to use our app to setup the timer instead of the system clock app.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"How to create a timer shortcut with shorter phrase for our app if the system already have one, for example, Set a timer for 5 mins, how can we tell the system to use our app to setup the timer instead of the system clock app."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Notably, App Shortcuts will need to include your app name, so that will help distinguish your phrases from standard Siri phrases. (i.e. “start a <app name> timer.“)

elements.text: Notably, App Shortcuts will need to include your app name, so that will help distinguish your phrases from standard Siri phrases. (i.e. “start a <app name> timer.“)

slackdump_thread_replies.text: With a particularly strong brand, you may even be able to skip the word timer. (i.e. “Start a Super Special Countdown”, assuming “Super Special Countdown is the app name)

elements.text: With a particularly strong brand, you may even be able to skip the word timer. (i.e. “Start a Super Special Countdown”, assuming “Super Special Countdown is the app name)

slackdump_thread_replies.text: A note though! You wouldn’t want to use “for <time value>” in your invocation phrase, because there are infinite possible replies. That’s better as an open-ended request, for a Duration

elements.text: A note though! You wouldn’t want to use “for <time value>” in your invocation phrase, because there are infinite possible replies. That’s better as an open-ended request, for a Duration

slackdump_thread_replies.text: <@U03HJ5M1UV8> I want to check I understand this. Is the distinction here that “open-ended requests” are always by definition follow-up requests after the invocation phrase? I wasn’t clear on this till now.

elements.text: I want to check I understand this. Is the distinction here that “open-ended requests” are always by definition follow-up requests after the invocation phrase? I wasn’t clear on this till now.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: There are a few different types of follow-up requests after the invocation phrase, and open-ended requests are one of them. Others are parameter confirmation, intent confirmation, and disambiguation.

elements.text: There are a few different types of follow-up requests after the invocation phrase, and open-ended requests are one of them. Others are parameter confirmation, intent confirmation, and disambiguation.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: But these are distinct from the dynamic parameter that you provide as part of your initial invocation

elements.text: But these are distinct from the dynamic parameter that you provide as part of your initial invocation

messages.text:
<@U03JRQ62JQY> asked
> Working on the prototyping team seems like such an incredible thing to be a part of. Can you tell us about your journeys to becoming prototypers at Apple? And what do you look for in potential candidates for your team?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Working on the prototyping team seems like such an incredible thing to be a part of. Can you tell us about your journeys to becoming prototypers at Apple? And what do you look for in potential candidates for your team?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: A lot of us some mix of backgrounds that don’t fit neatly into the typical design / engineering teams.

elements.text: A lot of us some mix of backgrounds that don’t fit neatly into the typical design / engineering teams.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Are there a lot of folks on the team who have a hard time identifying themselves as either designers or engineers, but actually both?

elements.text: Are there a lot of folks on the team who have a hard time identifying themselves as either designers or engineers, but actually both?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I taught myself programming outside of school and dabbled in a number of open source projects and the like. Realized I enjoyed psychology / cognitive science to learn more about how people think and approach technology. Studied Cognitive Science, HCI, and Communication Design in school. Had some design jobs but eventually accidentally found this team where I got to use my programming skills too!

elements.text: I taught myself programming outside of school and dabbled in a number of open source projects and the like. Realized I enjoyed psychology / cognitive science to learn more about how people think and approach technology. Studied Cognitive Science, HCI, and Communication Design in school. Had some design jobs but eventually accidentally found this team where I got to use my programming skills too!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: That’s amazing, thank you for sharing Julian :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: That’s amazing, thank you for sharing Julian

slackdump_thread_replies.text: That’s amazing!
A teammate was at an HCI conference (TEI '17) in Japan that I happened to have work in. He passed on my name to the recruiter. I studied Design and HCI in school, and then I interviewed!

elements.text: A teammate was at an HCI conference (TEI '17) in Japan that I happened to have work in. He passed on my name to the recruiter. I studied Design and HCI in school, and then I interviewed!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: That’s awesome, Marisa!

I studied computer science, spent some time in HCI academia, and worked for a few startups before joining Apple. For me making delightful interactive things has always been a single pursuit, and the boundaries between things like “design” and “engineering” never made too much sense to me. My teammates will have different answers but when I look at candidate portfolios, I like to see inspiration from fields beyond design & tech, a general sense of curiosity and playfulness… and just weird, unexpected, unique things! (even if they’re not the most polished)

For me making delightful interactive things has always been a single pursuit, and the boundaries between things like “design” and “engineering” never made too much sense to me. My teammates will have different answers but when I look at candidate portfolios, I like to see inspiration from fields beyond design & tech, a general sense of curiosity and playfulness… and just weird, unexpected, unique things! (even if they’re not the most polished)

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I was a fresh graduated from ECAL in Lausanne Switzerland, where I studied interaction design. A few months after that, Jeff our current Manager saw my bachelor graduation project on a blog and then reached out. It was such a suprise! I was super excited and curious to know more about the team and I end up joining in 2018. It was great that even though I had not much professional experience, the team was interested in my portfolio. When we are looking at candidate, I think we are interested about ideas and how the candidate communicates them, even if you have short resume like I did back then.

messages.text:
<@U03HMEA0C4X> asked
> Hey team! Im curious, when first designing a prototype of a new product, what would you say the ratio is of looks to functionality? Are looks secondary or are they the focus from the get go? Thanks :)

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Hey team! Im curious, when first designing a prototype of a new product, what would you say the ratio is of looks to functionality? Are looks secondary or are they the focus from the get go? Thanks :)"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I think the main thing is to think about what questions you are trying to answer by building one (or several) prototypes. Are they questions of technical feasibility, product usefulness,…? etc. Looks for the sake of looks are rarely worth spending lots of early prototyping time on, but sometimes different aesthetic directions or visual metaphors are definitely things you want to prototype!

elements.text: I think the main thing is to think about what questions you are trying to answer by building one (or several) prototypes. Are they questions of technical feasibility, product usefulness,…? etc. Looks for the sake of looks are rarely worth spending lots of early prototyping time on, but sometimes different aesthetic directions or visual metaphors are definitely things you want to prototype!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I’d add that the key balance to strike in prototyping is to make the least amount you need to make to still learn something. Sometimes that means things have to look very real so that you don’t distract from the part you’re trying to learn.

elements.text: I’d add that the key balance to strike in prototyping is to make the least amount you need to make to still learn something. Sometimes that means things have to look very real so that you don’t distract from the part you’re trying to learn.

<@U03JJD6G79B> asked
> How does your team go about quickly prototyping advanced interactions? I have lots of ideas for interactions I want to test but I feel my momentum is burnt out by the time I get everything set up in, say, a SwiftUI project.
