I have lots of ideas for interactions I want to test but I feel my momentum is burnt out by the time I get everything set up in, say, a SwiftUI project."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Finding a way to fake it! We talk about this in most of our old WWDC sessions, but Prototyping for AR (2018) has some good examples of finding clever ways to prototype that don’t involve code at all.

elements.text: Finding a way to fake it! We talk about this in most of our old WWDC sessions, but Prototyping for AR (2018) has some good examples of finding clever ways to prototype that don’t involve code at all.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: There are ways to fake things with paper printouts, or with clever video capture. But often doing some simple Keynote animations can teach a lot too.

elements.text: There are ways to fake things with paper printouts, or with clever video capture. But often doing some simple Keynote animations can teach a lot too.

messages.text:
<@U03JNAGPDS6> asked
> What types of products do you prototype, what's the process of making a design, and how many rough drafts do you usually have before finalizing anything?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"What types of products do you prototype, what's the process of making a design, and how many rough drafts do you usually have before finalizing anything?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Anything that Apple has shipped and might ship is the sort of thing we prototype! :slightly_smiling_face: I personally have worked a lot on cameras (iPhone, iPad) and Pencil over the years, as well as Watch and Health related features more recently. The process of making a design is generally making something, showing it to people, and learning from their feedback, and doing it over and over again. We've given a few WWDC talks on that topic over the years! We don't really count how many "drafts" we make, but everything we work on undergoes many, many iterations.

elements.text: Anything that Apple has shipped and might ship is the sort of thing we prototype!

I personally have worked a lot on cameras (iPhone, iPad) and Pencil over the years, as well as Watch and Health related features more recently. The process of making a design is generally making something, showing it to people, and learning from their feedback, and doing it over and over again. We've given a few WWDC talks on that topic over the years! We don't really count how many "drafts" we make, but everything we work on undergoes many, many iterations.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Are there differences between the final product hardware and software, or are the prototypes meant to test a specific feature and include some hardware and software features, but not all of it? aka. are you trying to test something with the mindset of a customer, or as a engineer?

elements.text: Are there differences between the final product hardware and software, or are the prototypes meant to test a specific feature and include some hardware and software features, but not all of it? aka. are you trying to test something with the mindset of a customer, or as a engineer?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The mindset of a customer, or a person using the product or feature. We collaborate closely with engineering teams that figure out feasibility. Our prototypes help them understand which use cases need to be supported.

elements.text: The mindset of a customer, or a person using the product or feature. We collaborate closely with engineering teams that figure out feasibility. Our prototypes help them understand which use cases need to be supported.

messages.text:
<@U03JE2RK60J> asked
> When creating prototypes, how extensively do you test it? i.e. Is it used only within the direct team or do you take the prototype to broader teams to test as well?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"When creating prototypes, how extensively do you test it? i.e. Is it used only within the direct team or do you take the prototype to broader teams to test as well?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Definitely show it to broader teams. It's less about testing in a traditional, thorough sense, and more about getting lots of people from different backgrounds to try it and tell us what they think.

elements.text: Definitely show it to broader teams. It's less about testing in a traditional, thorough sense, and more about getting lots of people from different backgrounds to try it and tell us what they think.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks <@U03HBKARTV4> :raised_hands: If I may ask a follow up question, what kind of feedback are you looking for when testing the prototype?

elements.text: If I may ask a follow up question, what kind of feedback are you looking for when testing the prototype?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We always build a prototype to answer questions, so what we're looking for will be about what that specific prototype is trying to answer. For example, when we were working on Scribble for iPad & Pencil, we wanted to really understand how people reacted to their handwriting being converted to digital text, what made that process more clear/understandable, what sorts of input would lead to confusion situations, and so on.

elements.text: We always build a prototype to answer questions, so what we're looking for will be about what that specific prototype is trying to answer. For example, when we were working on Scribble for iPad & Pencil, we wanted to really understand how people reacted to their handwriting being converted to digital text, what made that process more clear/understandable, what sorts of input would lead to confusion situations, and so on.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Awesome, thanks for the insight :bulb:

messages.text:
<@U03JENY84QH> asked
> What are some of the tools you use for prototyping?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"What are some of the tools you use for prototyping?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: As far as digital tools I personally use Sketch and Keynote a lot for static/2D interfaces, After Effects for animation, and Swift/UIKit/Core Animation/Metal when I need to make things a bit more real/custom or interface with hardware. But everyone on our team uses different tools and has workflows that work for them.

elements.text: As far as digital tools I personally use Sketch and Keynote a lot for static/2D interfaces, After Effects for animation, and Swift/UIKit/Core Animation/Metal when I need to make things a bit more real/custom or interface with hardware. But everyone on our team uses different tools and has workflows that work for them.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hi Sam! Making in the medium the design is meant to be in is important! For a prototype seeking to answer an interaction design question, interactive prototypes are essential. For the design of a graphic poster, print out poster iterations.

elements.text: Hi Sam! Making in the medium the design is meant to be in is important! For a prototype seeking to answer an interaction design question, interactive prototypes are essential. For the design of a graphic poster, print out poster iterations.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If the end artifact is meant to be spatial, then making in 3D is essential too

elements.text: If the end artifact is meant to be spatial, then making in 3D is essential too

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I'd say there's an underlying principle that the medium that one makes/prototypes in is also a very intentional choice, and should be chosen to best align with the desired end artifact

elements.text: I'd say there's an underlying principle that the medium that one makes/prototypes in is also a very intentional choice, and should be chosen to best align with the desired end artifact

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Give yourself time to _not_ worry so much about solving the problem. “What other ideas does this give us?” can mean completely unrelated things. But if they seem _interesting_ they’re worth trying. Those weird-but-interesting ideas can inspire us to connect the weird / whimsical inspiration to something that actually does solve the problem.

messages.text:
<@U03J7HT7DBR> asked
> When testing with people, how often do you change the prototype in between sessions, or not at all? i.e picking up issues from the first session and adjusting it before the next session. Is this recommended or should we stick to one prototype throughout?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"When testing with people, how often do you change the prototype in between sessions, or not at all? i.e picking up issues from the first session and adjusting it before the next session. Is this recommended or should we stick to one prototype throughout?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We try to keep more than one direction open at a time. It might mean having multiple very different prototypes, or one prototype than has sliders / prefs and can be adjusted. If someone gives us good feedback, we incorporate it or try it out. If it’s in conflict with the previous direction, we keep both around to let people compare.

elements.text: We try to keep more than one direction open at a time. It might mean having multiple very different prototypes, or one prototype than has sliders / prefs and can be adjusted. If someone gives us good feedback, we incorporate it or try it out. If it’s in conflict with the previous direction, we keep both around to let people compare.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: That’s great - thanks Julian. It makes sense to let people interact with different prototypes and observe, if I may ask, how flexible do you make prototypes? Are people allowed to tap on anything interactive on the screen, or is it limited to one flow?

elements.text: That’s great - thanks Julian. It makes sense to let people interact with different prototypes and observe, if I may ask, how flexible do you make prototypes? Are people allowed to tap on anything interactive on the screen, or is it limited to one flow?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: It’s usually very limited. We make it look like everything’s there, but only certain parts will be functional. It’s important that the rest look real because it’s often in the whole context of a product that we learn the most.

elements.text: It’s usually very limited. We make it look like everything’s there, but only certain parts will be functional. It’s important that the rest look real because it’s often in the whole context of a product that we learn the most.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks Julian.

messages.text:
<@U03JRDB98KB> asked
> When you're prototyping new ideas that are likely to meet some resistance (touch bar or dropping headphone jack), what process, if any other than just gut, do you have to decide whether to ship it or kill it?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"When you're prototyping new ideas that are likely to meet some resistance (touch bar or dropping headphone jack), what process, if any other than just gut, do you have to decide whether to ship it or kill it?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Generally our team doesn't get to decide whether to ship or kill things. Our job is to explore (by making prototypes) + document all the possible directions that seem interesting or plausible for a specific topic, share with relevant teams, and see what the reactions are. It happens that something we're very excited about is not something that makes it out the door for some reason, in those cases we tend to keep bringing it up in future work that touches on that concept, and work with teams inside the company who are excited about it too to try to build momentum together.

It happens that something we're very excited about is not something that makes it out the door for some reason, in those cases we tend to keep bringing it up in future work that touches on that concept, and work with teams inside the company who are excited about it too to try to build momentum together.

messages.text:
<@U03JENY84QH> asked
> What is the collaboration dynamic between the prototyping team and Design / Eng partners?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the collaboration dynamic between the prototyping team and Design \/ Eng partners?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We work closely with them! With engineering teams to understand the technical capabilities and limitations that we are working with, and with design teams to understand the roadmap they have for their products, and what problems they're trying to solve right now. The time horizon we work on (3-5 years) is a bit longer than the one most teams operate on, so communication is key for us to be aligned.

<@U03JRQ62JQY> asked
> I often find that because there are so many considerations to make for a design to be truly great, that can hamper my creativity and almost block me from making progress. Do you deal with similar things, and if so, how do you manage to stay creative and keep going?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"I often find that because there are so many considerations to make for a design to be truly great, that can hamper my creativity and almost block me from making progress. Do you deal with similar things, and if so, how do you manage to stay creative and keep going?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Absolutely! I think any creative in any field suffers from the "blank page" problem... for me I find that spending time doing things not tech/design related (playing music, spending time outdoors, reading books about random obscure topics,...) will often spark unexpected connections & inspiration that somehow find their way into my work. Something a little more specific I like to do too is to dive in the history of a topic I'm working on - for example the history of human mark making & handwriting through various cultures was very inspirational when I worked on Pencil.

messages.text:
<@U03JRP87THN> asked
> How do you come up with an idea of a product? For example, do you do brainstorming sessions? And how do you transform an idea into a prototype?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"How do you come up with an idea of a product? For example, do you do brainstorming sessions? And how do you transform an idea into a prototype?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I think it's important to know what the biggest questions around an idea you have, because that's what you'll want to prototype first. Is it about testing the usefulness of a feature? About exploring how to best display the results from an algorithm or machine learning model? Or is it about seeing if a new gesture interaction you came up with is easy for people to understand and perform? The goal of prototypes is to answer questions before investing a lot of time into making things real (hence why it's important to keep your prototyping process light & nimble). As far as coming up with ideas... ask people questions, and listen to what they have to say!

Or is it about seeing if a new gesture interaction you came up with is easy for people to understand and perform? The goal of prototypes is to answer questions before investing a lot of time into making things real (hence why it's important to keep your prototyping process light & nimble). As far as coming up with ideas... ask people questions, and listen to what they have to say!

messages.text:
<@U03HVE4TV8E> asked
> Hey! Firstly, it’s truly an honour to speak with this team and thank you for making products that impact each and every one of us each day :D As for my question, I would love to get better at design User Interfaces. What are the benefits of Sketch/Figma/etc. and would you recommend their usage? Thanks!

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Hey! Firstly, it\u2019s truly an honour to speak with this team and thank you for making products that impact each and every one of us each day :D As for my question, I would love to get better at design User Interfaces. What are the benefits of Sketch\/Figma\/etc. and would you recommend their usage? Thanks!"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Sketch and Figma are two popular tools for UI design and prototyping, but ultimately they're just tools - they won't give you magical results on their own. If you'd like to get better at designing UIs and you're starting from scratch I'd encourage you to focus more on things like layout, type, color, interaction patterns (the Apple HIG is a great place to get started on those topics as they specifically pertain to Apple platforms! <https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/>) than focusing on a specific tool.

attachments.fallback: Human Interface Guidelines - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
attachments.title: Human Interface Guidelines - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
attachments.text: Human Interface Guidelines

elements.text: Sketch and Figma are two popular tools for UI design and prototyping, but ultimately they're just tools - they won't give you magical results on their own. If you'd like to get better at designing UIs and you're starting from scratch I'd encourage you to focus more on things like layout, type, color, interaction patterns (the Apple HIG is a great place to get started on those topics as they specifically pertain to Apple platforms!
) than focusing on a specific tool.

messages.text:
<@U03HMEA0C4X> asked
> I saw Julian mention the process of 'Make things, Show them to people, Learn from their feedback' and I was wondering if you've ever had a product that's had little to no changes after feedback? A product thats a hole in one? And how much does the product usually change after feedback?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"I saw Julian mention the process of 'Make things, Show them to people, Learn from their feedback' and I was wondering if you've ever had a product that's had little to no changes after feedback? A product thats a hole in one? And how much does the product usually change after feedback?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Never.

If we’re not getting feedback on something, we’re just not showing it to the right people. We will eventually show it to someone who will have feedback about it (improvements or reasons why it won’t work!)

elements.text: If we’re not getting feedback on something, we’re just not showing it to the right people. We will eventually show it to someone who will have feedback about it (improvements or reasons why it won’t work!)

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Things change a lot between our first conception of it and what makes it out the door. That’s the fun part about working with a whole lot of people who are very talented at what they do.

elements.text: Things change a lot between our first conception of it and what makes it out the door. That’s the fun part about working with a whole lot of people who are very talented at what they do.

Always bring positive feedback when sharing the work. It should never be about personal judgement but how to make your app experience better.
For example:
"I don't like this color" vs "I think blue instead of read would better communicate what the experience is about"

<@U03HVE4TV8E> asked
> Is there ever a time where you have to stop and refocus the vision or design? Like, if too many new ideas have been added and the original focus has been lost?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Is there ever a time where you have to stop and refocus the vision or design? Like, if too many new ideas have been added and the original focus has been lost?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yes, but usually not because of too many new ideas! If there are too many new ideas it means we have a lot we can try out.

elements.text: Yes, but usually not because of too many new ideas! If there are too many new ideas it means we have a lot we can try out.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yes absolutely. When that happens we typically try to focus on what it was that people loved the most in that set of work. If you have dozens of things competing for your attention, focusing on the 2-3 that really seem to be winning hearts over is often a good way to move forward without getting bogged down. But sometimes you also have to accept that while you may have a bunch of kind of cool things, there's nothing in there that's a true winner. And that's okay! There's always way for those things you liked but which weren't clear winners to make their way into other work in the future.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The purpose of prototypes is to help advance the conversation. Instead of going in circles verbally about what might be, we start to talk about what’s in front of us. Or what could be in front of us that we haven’t made yet!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Which is to say, we often find the things we think are interesting change dramatically once we have a few prototypes in front of us. And we have conversations about that!

messages.text:
<@U03J23RAFK4> asked
> Do you differentiate between designing user interfaces and prototyping? Are they related or separate focuses?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Do you differentiate between designing user interfaces and prototyping? Are they related or separate focuses?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yes they are definitely 2 different things, although for us they overlap a lot! I think prototyping in general refers to building artefacts quickly to answer questions that will then inform how to build something "for real". So Apple also has silicon prototypers working on the M series chips, for instance! For us, we prototype interactions and user interfaces, which means we try to explore what new modes of input or new capabilities (think for example something like FaceID/Depth Camera, or Apple Pencil) would bring to our products, which then informs whether the company should invest the resources in actually building that hardware/product.

elements.text: Yes they are definitely 2 different things, although for us they overlap a lot! I think prototyping in general refers to building artefacts quickly to answer questions that will then inform how to build something "for real". So Apple also has silicon prototypers working on the M series chips, for instance! For us, we prototype interactions and user interfaces, which means we try to explore what new modes of input or new capabilities (think for example something like FaceID/Depth Camera, or Apple Pencil) would bring to our products, which then informs whether the company should invest the resources in actually building that hardware/product.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: It depends on what the prototype is trying to answer and at what stage of the project we are. But generally a polished UI would help better communicate with other teams, make it look real.

elements.text: It depends on what the prototype is trying to answer and at what stage of the project we are. But generally a polished UI would help better communicate with other teams, make it look real.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks for the answers! So sometimes it involves building a UI, but much more and not just limited to a digital UI with prototyping.

elements.text: Thanks for the answers! So sometimes it involves building a UI, but much more and not just limited to a digital UI with prototyping.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Though sometimes we can get away with re-using large parts of the existing designs.

elements.text: Though sometimes we can get away with re-using large parts of the existing designs.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I’m not sure we’re necessarily doing _more_ — the final user interface designs require a lot of work to be designed for all the different devices, screen sizes, edge cases, accessibility cases, error cases… we’re fortunate to get to pass on that until it becomes a specific issue for our concept. We build on what’s already there for those parts.

messages.text:
<@U03JENY84QH> asked
> Have you ever had to build a new tool in order to design a new experience? Do you ever use custom or internal prototyping tools that apple makes?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Have you ever had to build a new tool in order to design a new experience? Do you ever use custom or internal prototyping tools that apple makes?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yes! And yes! The “tools” are a lot rougher than you might have in mind, but we’re often cobbling together our own sets of code to be able to try things. We don’t build it out into a generic reusable tool as much as we build the frameworks / scaffolding necessary to try out the very-specific thing we want to get into our hands.

elements.text: Yes! And yes! The “tools” are a lot rougher than you might have in mind, but we’re often cobbling together our own sets of code to be able to try things. We don’t build it out into a generic reusable tool as much as we build the frameworks / scaffolding necessary to try out the very-specific thing we want to get into our hands.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We build what’s necessary to try the specific things we want to try. We try really hard to stay away from prematurely abstracting. It’s too easy to accidentally become a framework engineer or tools engineer when we really were just trying to try something out.

elements.text: We build what’s necessary to try the specific things we want to try. We try really hard to stay away from prematurely abstracting. It’s too easy to accidentally become a framework engineer or tools engineer when we really were just trying to try something out.

activity with the team that does UX writing at Apple. This session is the first we've ever done on this topic so don't miss it!

And just to seed some questions in here:
• What do you think are the future trends of design? :crystal_ball:
• Do you have a mentor? How have they helped you? If not, what are you looking for in a mentor?
• If you were allowed to redesign one product, what would it be?

messages.text:
:wave: Hi, everyone. Welcome to *Meet the Presenters:* *Writing for interfaces.* I'm Sarah and I'm a UX Writer here at Apple.

Here in the chat, we'll be watching *Writing for interfaces* with our two amazing presenters and fellow Apple UX Writers :sparkles:<@U03HVEWEGAF> and <@U03HWQ6F9A5>:sparkles:. After we watch, they'll answer any questions you may have.

Whether you call it copy, strings, or text, this session will give some best practices relating to choosing the right words in your app's interface. :writing_hand::skin-tone-2::writing_hand::skin-tone-2::writing_hand::skin-tone-2:

elements.text:
I'm Sarah and I'm a UX Writer here at Apple.

Here in the chat, we'll be watching
with our two amazing presenters and fellow Apple UX Writers

. After we watch, they'll answer any questions you may have.

Whether you call it copy, strings, or text, this session will give some best practices relating to choosing the right words in your app's interface.

messages.text: :thread: Let's start with our *P*—for *Purpose.* How do you use words to explain the purpose of your app?

elements.text: How do you use words to explain the purpose of your app?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Tab bar labels often capture the purpose of the app, when they're done well

elements.text: Tab bar labels often capture the purpose of the app, when they're done well

slackdump_thread_replies.text: In my opinion, anyway. :sweat_smile:
Seems to me that the words describing purpose of an app start on the App Store - not in your app.

elements.text: Seems to me that the words describing purpose of an app start on the App Store - not in your app.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: That’s a great point. Think about the writing beyond just what’s inside the app.

elements.text: That’s a great point. Think about the writing beyond just what’s inside the app.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: It's a really good point, <@U03J1UGE04B>. By the time people are launching an app for the first time, they've already begun the experience with it, with the app name, app icon, the screenshots in the App Store, the description, etc

elements.text: . By the time people are launching an app for the first time, they've already begun the experience with it, with the app name, app icon, the screenshots in the App Store, the description, etc

messages.text:
<@U03K6K2J79P> asked
> Other than users and learners, any other suggestions for referring to the people using our apps?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Other than users and learners, any other suggestions for referring to the people using our apps?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: What is your audience? We often just use “people” but if you can be more specific, like “family member” or “subscriber” that’s a good way to go.

elements.text: What is your audience? We often just use “people” but if you can be more specific, like “family member” or “subscriber” that’s a good way to go.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Think about what people using your app would call themselves.

elements.text: Think about what people using your app would call themselves.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We try to avoid the word “users” when we refer the people who use our apps, and prefer something that sounds more human, like "artists",  "collaborators", "participants", etc. depending on the app and what people are trying to do. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: We try to avoid the word “users” when we refer the people who use our apps, and prefer something that sounds more human, like "artists",  "collaborators", "participants", etc. depending on the app and what people are trying to do.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thank you! That is very helpful :relaxed:

elements.text: Thank you! That is very helpful

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The _voice_ of your app is something you want to remain consistent, so that folks get consistent messaging inside your app. But, as you point out, the _tone_ can certainly modulate. When you welcome somebody, you might sound excited. But when that person has a credit card declined, you may want to sound more serious.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Great question. One way to think about it, is that your product is a major part of your brand.

With that in mind, your product may have more specific guidelines to follow so that you can make your interface feel familiar — and subsequently, intuitive. These kinds of patterns are outlined in the the Human Interface Guidelines.

Your brand, however, may encompass more than just what appears in your product. Your website, emails, marketing collaterals, events, and even the App Store descriptions mentioned earlier, these are all examples of surfaces where your voice extends beyond your app. For us, that's where the Apple Style Guide kicks in, helping us to adhere to a wider set of grammar and syntax to ensure we have consistency at every customer touchpoint.

Think about this balance for your app, too. How can your app have clarity and consistency throughout, and how can that narrative continue outside of your app to complement what you — and your users — are trying to do?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"For full screen modals with no interaction, is Apple's preferred dismiss control an X in a circle in the top right corner (as is referenced in the Explore Navigation Design for iOS talk) as opposed to a grab style control at the top middle (indicating to pull down to close)?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Great question! I’ve been wondering this myself recently :facepunch:
Totally great question. we get it a lot. We have an answer for you in the HIG: <https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/components/presentation/sheets>

attachments.fallback: Sheets - Presentation - Components - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
attachments.title: Sheets - Presentation - Components - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
attachments.text: A sheet helps people perform a scoped task that’s closely related to their current context.

elements.text: Totally great question. we get it a lot. We have an answer for you in the HIG:

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Position Done and Cancel buttons as people expect. Typically, a Done or Dismiss button belongs in a sheet’s top-right corner (in a left-to-right layout) or top-left corner (in a right-to-left layout). The Cancel button belongs in a sheet’s top-left (in a left-to-right layout) or top-right (in a right-to-left layout) corner.

elements.text: Position Done and Cancel buttons as people expect. Typically, a Done or Dismiss button belongs in a sheet’s top-right corner (in a left-to-right layout) or top-left corner (in a right-to-left layout). The Cancel button belongs in a sheet’s top-left (in a left-to-right layout) or top-right (in a right-to-left layout) corner.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Good question <@U03JRQUJ27J>. This has been an interaction pattern in recent releases, moving away from the elevated sheet and toward the full-screen presentation with the close in the top right

elements.text: . This has been an interaction pattern in recent releases, moving away from the elevated sheet and toward the full-screen presentation with the close in the top right

messages.text:
<@U03HVE4TV8E> asked
> If you add a new feature to an app, is it a good idea to showcase that new feature when the user does a certain action (i.e. completes a task etc.) or is that bad user experience as you’re interrupting their session? Thanks :grin:

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"If you add a new feature to an app, is it a good idea to showcase that new feature when the user does a certain action (i.e. completes a task etc.) or is that bad user experience as you\u2019re interrupting their session? Thanks "},{"type":"emoji","name":"grin"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: This goes back to context. If that feature is relevant or helpful at that moment, then yes, go ahead and talk about the new feature. But if it’s not relevant to that moment, think about where else it would feel more contextual.

elements.text: This goes back to context. If that feature is relevant or helpful at that moment, then yes, go ahead and talk about the new feature. But if it’s not relevant to that moment, think about where else it would feel more contextual.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: That’s great, thanks :blush:

messages.text:
<@U03JELQLESV> asked
> Seems common for interface copy to be too verbose before it's edited down. Are there examples that come to mind where the UI was the opposite, too terse and needed more explanation?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Seems common for interface copy to be too verbose before it's edited down. Are there examples that come to mind where the UI was the opposite, too terse and needed more explanation?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: There are may examples of this, I'm sure. One that comes to mind is when people input personal information, like when ordering something for delivery to their home. Sure, you could just indicate that you received the information, but by restating what you received (so the customer can ensure it was entered correctly) and maybe even stating that the info won't be used for nefarious purposes (eg. it wont be sold to advertisers), you create a level of comfort that more economical language might not afford.

elements.text: There are may examples of this, I'm sure. One that comes to mind is when people input personal information, like when ordering something for delivery to their home. Sure, you could just indicate that you received the information, but by restating what you received (so the customer can ensure it was entered correctly) and maybe even stating that the info won't be used for nefarious purposes (eg. it wont be sold to advertisers), you create a level of comfort that more economical language might not afford.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Think about when you tell a server at a restaurant that you want a certain dish, but with extra pickles and hot sauce but no tomatoes and can you please switch the fries for a salad. Some servers won't write that down. And while that's impressive to see, it's also nice to hear when the server repeats it back to you so you know the meal will come as you asked.

elements.text: Think about when you tell a server at a restaurant that you want a certain dish, but with extra pickles and hot sauce but no tomatoes and can you please switch the fries for a salad. Some servers won't write that down. And while that's impressive to see, it's also nice to hear when the server repeats it back to you so you know the meal will come as you asked.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Love that metaphor <@U03HJ5LRUEN>. Another thing we do often is link out to support articles for people who want to learn more about a particular subject. That way the information is there if you need, but it's not in the way.

elements.text: . Another thing we do often is link out to support articles for people who want to learn more about a particular subject. That way the information is there if you need, but it's not in the way.

<@U03J20RJQ2X> asked
> Sorry for joining so late! I make a photo editing app and I often wonder how I should deal with technical terms. One example that comes to mind are blend modes (screen, overlay, multiply, etc.) as those things are foreign concepts to the average person. Do you recommend sticking to such technical terms and providing explanations via graphics, for example?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Sorry for joining so late! I make a photo editing app and I often wonder how I should deal with technical terms. One example that comes to mind are blend modes (screen, overlay, multiply, etc.) as those things are foreign concepts to the average person. Do you recommend sticking to such technical terms and providing explanations via graphics, for example?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Ooh good question. It really depends on your audience - are they professional photographers? Then they might understand more technical terms. You can also help define things with secondary text.

elements.text: Ooh good question. It really depends on your audience - are they professional photographers? Then they might understand more technical terms. You can also help define things with secondary text.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks for the reply! The app is not targeted at professionals, so I’ve tried to find ways to better communicate what those tools do

elements.text: Thanks for the reply! The app is not targeted at professionals, so I’ve tried to find ways to better communicate what those tools do

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If these are terms of art, and it sounds like they are, it can be best to stick with them. Avoid jargon, or making up terms that might end up confusing everyone. That said, if your audience is less technical, maybe define the terms so people can learn them.

elements.text: If these are terms of art, and it sounds like they are, it can be best to stick with them. Avoid jargon, or making up terms that might end up confusing everyone. That said, if your audience is less technical, maybe define the terms so people can learn them.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: +1 to what <@U03HWQ6F9A5> and <@U03HVEWEGAF> said here. We aim to democratize access to technology with much of our hardware, software, and services at Apple; so we aim to have our language be understood by as many people as possible. But with a few of our apps, we have a specific audience (eg our creator tools, like Apple Music for Artists, that focus on specific audiences), and therefore we want the language to be in the vernacular of the users—otherwise it may feel like we've shipped a watered-down professional feature.

elements.text: said here. We aim to democratize access to technology with much of our hardware, software, and services at Apple; so we aim to have our language be understood by as many people as possible. But with a few of our apps, we have a specific audience (eg our creator tools, like Apple Music for Artists, that focus on specific audiences), and therefore we want the language to be in the vernacular of the users—otherwise it may feel like we've shipped a watered-down professional feature.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Since it's not aimed at professionals, show it to friends (or strangers) and see if they understand what's written. And as Jen and Kaely pointed out in their talk, consider reading it out loud to yourself as well.

elements.text: Since it's not aimed at professionals, show it to friends (or strangers) and see if they understand what's written. And as Jen and Kaely pointed out in their talk, consider reading it out loud to yourself as well.

messages.text:
:thread: Let’s talk about tabbed navigation! Have you seen the updated tab bar page on the Human Interface Guidelines? Does your app use a tab bar?
<https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/components/navigation-and-search/tab-bars>

attachments.fallback: Tab bars - Navigation And-search - Components - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
attachments.title: Tab bars - Navigation And-search - Components - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
attachments.text: Tab bars use bar items to navigate between mutually exclusive panes of content in the same view.

elements.text: Let’s talk about tabbed navigation! Have you seen the updated tab bar page on the Human Interface Guidelines? Does your app use a tab bar?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I use tabs I'm apps. Makes the most sense for me and I think users.
Should tab bar button items always automatically scroll to the top when the tab is already active?

elements.text: Should tab bar button items always automatically scroll to the top when the tab is already active?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: It's also very reachable!
<@U03HBHWCB4N> want to answer a question early?

elements.text: want to answer a question early?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: this is really good. I had a discussion with my business partner about having everything in the the main view or separate it in a tab bar

elements.text: this is really good. I had a discussion with my business partner about having everything in the the main view or separate it in a tab bar

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I can wait until the Q&A after also! :sweat_smile:

elements.text: I can wait until the Q&A after also!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Tabs are great, easy to implement and to grasp for a user. The thing that mostly confused me in the past where designers misusing these concepts, e.g. by adding an action to a tab icon.

elements.text: Tabs are great, easy to implement and to grasp for a user. The thing that mostly confused me in the past where designers misusing these concepts, e.g. by adding an action to a tab icon.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: <@U03JRNE4KJL> Totally, those are toolbars! Actions = toolbars. Navigation = tab bars

elements.text: Totally, those are toolbars! Actions = toolbars. Navigation = tab bars

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If I’m understanding your question correctly, <@U03JELQLESV>, your tabs should maintain state. They should be scrolled to the top of view on first launch and when the screen scrolls, even if a person taps another tab, the previous one should maintain state.

elements.text: If I’m understanding your question correctly,
, your tabs should maintain state. They should be scrolled to the top of view on first launch and when the screen scrolls, even if a person taps another tab, the previous one should maintain state.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: What got lost in recent years where configurable tab bars - rarely any apps uses the system implementation anymore, rather e.g. after long-press a user can exchange the current tab content - would be cool to have system support for that!

elements.text: What got lost in recent years where configurable tab bars - rarely any apps uses the system implementation anymore, rather e.g. after long-press a user can exchange the current tab content - would be cool to have system support for that!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Really loved the the screen tree in the session, made things super clear. <@U03HBGQ6V2S> Great job! :clap:

elements.text: Really loved the the screen tree in the session, made things super clear.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks <@U03HBGQ6V2S>! I mean if the user scrolls down in the active tab view, and then taps that same tab (not a different one), should it be expected that the view jumps back to the top? Just wondering because I think I've seen this happen in some apps, but in other apps nothing happens.

elements.text: ! I mean if the user scrolls down in the active tab view, and then taps that same tab (not a different one), should it be expected that the view jumps back to the top? Just wondering because I think I've seen this happen in some apps, but in other apps nothing happens.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yes, tapping the currently selected button in a tab bar *should* scroll the content view to the top. Also, tapping the status bar. But this is really a power feature. Not sure how many people are aware of this functionality.

elements.text: Yes, tapping the currently selected button in a tab bar
scroll the content view to the top. Also, tapping the status bar. But this is really a power feature. Not sure how many people are aware of this functionality.

messages.text: :thread: No Home Tabs! This isn't even a question, just a statement :stuck_out_tongue:

elements.text: No Home Tabs! This isn't even a question, just a statement

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Can you please tell this to my Manager and Designers directly… Every time I have to fight not to have a Home tabs.

Most of our Home tabs are just buttons that switch tabs, or show the content of the individual tabs twice :man-facepalming:

elements.text:
Can you please tell this to my Manager and Designers directly… Every time I have to fight not to have a Home tabs.

Most of our Home tabs are just buttons that switch tabs, or show the content of the individual tabs twice

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Tell them that Apple designers will be very disappointed to see a home tab in their UI :white_frowning_face:

elements.text: Tell them that Apple designers will be very disappointed to see a home tab in their UI

slackdump_thread_replies.text: And point them to this video!

elements.text: And point them to this video!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: How do you feel about a “more” . . .  button

elements.text: How do you feel about a “more” . . .  button

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We're not fans of those either in the tab bar. They're very non-descriptive of the content that's inside and end up being a giant junk drawer in most IRL cases. Similar to the dreaded hamburger menu! Better to be purposeful about what the menu contains for navigation purposes and give it a specific  name and icon.

elements.text: We're not fans of those either in the tab bar. They're very non-descriptive of the content that's inside and end up being a giant junk drawer in most IRL cases. Similar to the dreaded hamburger menu! Better to be purposeful about what the menu contains for navigation purposes and give it a specific  name and icon.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Can you talk about what you see as the differences between a "For You" / "Today" tab and a "Home" tab? I agree a tab that just links to other tabs isn't particularly useful but a general recommendations tab is a common paradigm too

elements.text: Can you talk about what you see as the differences between a "For You" / "Today" tab and a "Home" tab? I agree a tab that just links to other tabs isn't particularly useful but a general recommendations tab is a common paradigm too

messages.text:
<@U03K1SMSPUZ> asked
> In reference to not creating a "home" tab, what are your thoughts on having "cards" that are overviews of content from a different tab? Would you consider that a duplicate?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"In reference to not creating a \"home\" tab, what are your thoughts on having \"cards\" that are overviews of content from a different tab? Would you consider that a duplicate?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hey <@U03K1SMSPUZ>, great question. This is highly dependent of the context and content of the app. Be cautious of cards that display unrelated or disparate types of information and make an interface feel like a dashboard. Dashboards are similar to Home tabs, as the information is not directly related and often overloaded. This makes it difficult to glance and takes longer to understand the relationships and how to take action

elements.text: , great question. This is highly dependent of the context and content of the app. Be cautious of cards that display unrelated or disparate types of information and make an interface feel like a dashboard. Dashboards are similar to Home tabs, as the information is not directly related and often overloaded. This makes it difficult to glance and takes longer to understand the relationships and how to take action

slackdump_thread_replies.text: So, if you use cards or have a dashboard like view, try to keep the content relevant to the current tab?

elements.text: So, if you use cards or have a dashboard like view, try to keep the content relevant to the current tab?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We’ve seen some apps that have a wide array of Widgets that can be configured like a dashboard. It can be very powerful, especially on iPad. But these widgets would take you to the corresponding tab in the app.

elements.text: We’ve seen some apps that have a wide array of Widgets that can be configured like a dashboard. It can be very powerful, especially on iPad. But these widgets would take you to the corresponding tab in the app.

messages.text:
<@U03KA893DUY> asked
> when do you recommend hiding the navigation bar when pushing a view?
> Ex: Apple News: When you open an article, the app pushes the article view and hides the main navigation.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"when do you recommend hiding the navigation bar when pushing a view?\nEx: Apple News: When you open an article, the app pushes the article view and hides the main navigation."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Curious about if there are situations when the tab bar should be hidden also.

elements.text: Curious about if there are situations when the tab bar should be hidden also.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: It’s true that News doesn’t follow the typical convention we recommend for tabbed apps. I can’t really speak for the News team, but I believe the thinking was that people don’t generally switch between tabs frequently or want to persist state in each tab since the content changes all the time

elements.text: It’s true that News doesn’t follow the typical convention we recommend for tabbed apps. I can’t really speak for the News team, but I believe the thinking was that people don’t generally switch between tabs frequently or want to persist state in each tab since the content changes all the time

slackdump_thread_replies.text: People drill into articles, read, and then often leave.

elements.text: People drill into articles, read, and then often leave.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
You could consider temporarily hide the Navigation Bar for immersive experiences, just be sure to allow
the reverse interaction and show it when swiping down or tapping the screen.

elements.text:
You could consider temporarily hide the Navigation Bar for immersive experiences, just be sure to allow
the reverse interaction and show it when swiping down or tapping the screen.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: In that usage pattern, persisting the tab bar to allow for fast lateral navigation, or keeping it visible to help people stay oriented, is less of an imperative.

elements.text: In that usage pattern, persisting the tab bar to allow for fast lateral navigation, or keeping it visible to help people stay oriented, is less of an imperative.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: This is pretty atypical for tabbed apps though

elements.text: This is pretty atypical for tabbed apps though

slackdump_thread_replies.text: got it! Yes I was thinking it can be also be possible to use a modal instead of a push with hidden nav bar

elements.text: got it! Yes I was thinking it can be also be possible to use a modal instead of a push with hidden nav bar

messages.text:
<@U03HVE4TV8E> asked
> I saw in the session that there are list section headers that are bold and bigger than normal section headers. In which cases should we use these? Thanks

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"I saw in the session that there are list section headers that are bold and bigger than normal section headers. In which cases should we use these? Thanks "}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: They’re a relative recent change to iOS (last year I think). It’s a matter of taste and judgement I think. But they’re particularly effective when the list is text only. It helps created needed differentiation (or grouping) between content items and category labels

elements.text: They’re a relative recent change to iOS (last year I think). It’s a matter of taste and judgement I think. But they’re particularly effective when the list is text only. It helps created needed differentiation (or grouping) between content items and category labels

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If the list items are visually distinctive, larger section headers might not be needed. But, personally, I think they’re an improvement in all situations.

elements.text: If the list items are visually distinctive, larger section headers might not be needed. But, personally, I think they’re an improvement in all situations.

messages.text:
<@U03J1UPA8UB> asked
> "Home" is such a lazy name for the app's first tab! But the argument that's often given in its favour is that people understand it because that's how the first page is often referred to in web and app design and changing it would mean forcing people to change their already established habits.
> 
> Would Spotify / Twitter doing away with the home tab be a risky UI move that could lose them followers or a much needed navigation cleanse?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hard to say a blanket "yes or no" because it depends on the content inside the tab. We do "For You" tabs where the content inside changes dynamically based on what we think is relevant to the user. That could be considered a "featured" section but its use case is specific enough from navigation that it can be its own page

messages.text:
<@U03J1TN6WBD> asked
> In the "Explore navigation design for iOS" session there is an example of a "Profile" Tab which I've seen several apps using, but others like f.e. the Appstore uses Profile as button in the top-right side.
> Does that depend on the importance of such a Profile screen ?
> in other words, What makes something to be a "tab-worthy" ?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"In the \"Explore navigation design for iOS\" session there is an example of a \"Profile\" Tab which I've seen several apps using, but others like f.e. the Appstore uses Profile as button in the top-right side.\nDoes that depend on the importance of such a Profile screen ?\nin other words, What makes something to be a \"tab-worthy\" ?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Great question, <@U03J1TN6WBD>. This is a judgement call based off of the importance of the profile. In many cases, the profile is not that important to the apps main functionality and it isn’t needed as a tab bar item.

elements.text: . This is a judgement call based off of the importance of the profile. In many cases, the profile is not that important to the apps main functionality and it isn’t needed as a tab bar item.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: When considering what should be a tab, think of your apps menu of options. When tabs are designed well, they tell a story at a glance about what your app can do and how people can use it. Profile tends to be less important in the scheme of things.

elements.text: When considering what should be a tab, think of your apps menu of options. When tabs are designed well, they tell a story at a glance about what your app can do and how people can use it. Profile tends to be less important in the scheme of things.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: And just because you have tabs to use, doesn’t mean you have to use them all. Sometimes an app will feel more approachable if the tabbed navigation is simplified

elements.text: And just because you have tabs to use, doesn’t mean you have to use them all. Sometimes an app will feel more approachable if the tabbed navigation is simplified

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Agree with <@U03HBHWCB4N>. Also, if the user needs to access the Profile content regularly and you don’t want to place a profile button in the nav bar of every tab, a profile tab may be a better option.

elements.text: . Also, if the user needs to access the Profile content regularly and you don’t want to place a profile button in the nav bar of every tab, a profile tab may be a better option.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Side note I wish the Updates tab were restored in App Store, I check for app updates multiple times a day and read the release notes. Def inefficient to open the profile screen. (Yes I might have a problem :laughing:)

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
<@U03JRNE4KJL> I totally understand how this could be confusing. You’re right, top right accessories are used for the main actions. But in the case of Modals there might be other resources more suitable - like buttons - to convey important actions. So Close takes the top right place.
I’d say that prioritization of the actions on screen are key here, once you have a clear understanding - you could decide what’s the best pattern to follow.

messages.text:
<@U03J20EAJKV> asked
> It struck me that tab bars and navigation bars are, at least in principle, identical to the original iPhone interaction paradigm. I’m wondering what the biggest difference you’ve seen in navigation is, since that first iPhone?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"It struck me that tab bars and navigation bars are, at least in principle, identical to the original iPhone interaction paradigm. I\u2019m wondering what the biggest difference you\u2019ve seen in navigation is, since that first iPhone?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I love this question. I wish I had the time to answer more thoroughly. Here are some thoughts about tab bars and navigation bars: these components and interaction patterns clearly resonated with people. Maybe that was luck, maybe it’s a pattern that reflected our natural understanding of how things are organized and arranged already in the world around us. But they have evolved and modernized while staying true to what ‘just worked’ originally. As people’s comfort with apps grow, new patterns emerge to support new complexity such as sidebar being a solution specific to a new device and form factor

I knew to schedule my Design Lab as early as possible & it was very much worth it, thanks again.

Whilst the 1-1 labs are great (and unfortunately short), I've had huge benefit from these Slacks. It helped a lot when questions were able to be logged out of ours. I'm in Perth, same zone as Singapore, so it's been an exhausting week.

On that topic, I think if similar formats next year, worth warning people up front they should try to schedule living a shifted time for the week, even though remote, because there's so much valuable time-restricted interaction.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Design is an area where I can always _ask more_ especially frustratingly when there are entire controls and idioms not documented (like swipe to reveal buttons).

It would be nice to have some kind of linkage from the HIG to a HIP (Human Interface Proposals) discussion forum for doc extensions. This idea inspired by the Swift language forums I participate in (99.5% lurking) and Python's long PEP forum history.

This is for WWDC22 in general and what we could make better for you. Your feedback has major impact on the programs and events we host. :pray::sparkling_heart:

attachments.title: Apple
attachments.text: Thanks for joining us this year. WWDC is designed for you and your feedback is important to us. Providing responses to this survey is voluntary. It should take 5 minutes or less of your time. Do not include any information that may identify you in the text boxes. Your responses will not be tied to you and will be aggregated with other responses.

_(This is a kind of feedback, but not sure if this thread is the right place. I can move the message if needed)_ 

I wanted to express my gratitude to all of you at the design team for all the content you folks create.

The past few years have been tough for me to find inspiration and motivation, but your WWDC sessions (_and the HIG_) became my go-to when wanting to spark some creative process, or when wanting to feel excitement about the things we all create.
Once again, thank you very much!

messages.text:
<@U03JELM0ZNV> asked
> I have heavy use of swipe buttons on different rows of a "tree control". (TableView with lots of different cell types).
> 
> I've not found any recent writing on swipe button discoverability but watching people, _average users_ don't seem to explore to see if swipes are available on lists. 
> 
> Any suggestions on affordances or onboarding approaches? I've thought about an initial animation of sliding things over enough for a button to _peek_ through.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Since swipe actions are more for power users, we always recommend that they are _also_ exposed in the detail view. For example, if there’s a delete action on your table cell, make sure there’s a delete action in a toolbar, navigation bar or in-line within the secondary view.

elements.text: Since swipe actions are more for power users, we always recommend that they are
exposed in the detail view. For example, if there’s a delete action on your table cell, make sure there’s a delete action in a toolbar, navigation bar or in-line within the secondary view.

messages.text:
<@U03JGS1CE2H> asked
> Hi, I really enjoyed the session on the new iPad navigation bar for document-based apps. I just did a lab to explore this further - one of the suggestions was to adopt a layout/hierarchy similar to the Notes app. 
> 
> I wanted to ask if there is any API for the file explorer (lists and grid view) that the Notes app uses. I would like to adopt this in a sidebar as well, and move my document-based app away from a tab controller. Thanks.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Hi <@U03JGS1CE2H>, thank you for the question, I’m not sure about an API specifically (I’m just a designer!). But here are two resources from the session side that may be helpful for you:
1. The session Designed for iPad, which dives deep into the design for Sidebar 
<https://developer.apple.com/wwdc20/10206>

2. This year’s session about Desktop Class iPad apps which covers some tips for the new toolbar design
<https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/10009>
